resources.string: ADA Access, meant for use on Android platforms and created under the MIT License, is designed for storing and displaying architectural standards set in place by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) most recently updated in 2010. These standards include specifications for handicap-accessible construction of dorms, social service centers, medical care facilities, etc. These specifications include door widths and ramp angles and lengths, among many more specific measurements and requirements. ADA Access makes it easy and efficient to access these standards when in the field or when a stationary and/or written source is not available.

• Door openings must provide a clear minimum width of 32 inches. 
 
 • Hinged doors must open 90 degrees. 
 
 • Thresholds cannot be more than one-half inch high. 
 
 Maneuvering clearances for swinging doors: 
 • Approach from front, pull: Minimum 60 inches perpendicular to doorway and 18 inches parallel to doorway. 
 
 • Approach from front, push: Minimum 48 inches perpendicular to doorway and 0 inches parallel to doorway. 
 
 • Approach from hinge side, pull: Minimum 60 inches perpendicular to doorway and 36 inches parallel to doorway. 
 
 • Approach from hinge side, push: Minimum 42 inches perpendicular to doorway and 22 inches parallel to doorway. 
 
 • Approach from latch/knob side, pull: Minimum 48 inches perpendicular to doorway and 24 inches parallel to doorway. 
 
 • Approach from latch/knob side, push: Minimum 42 inches perpendicular to doorway and 24 inches parallel to doorway. 
 
 • See Section 404 for more detail and graphics.

• Door openings must provide a clear minimum width of 32 inches. 
 
 • Hinged doors must open 90 degrees. 
 
 • Thresholds cannot be more than one-half inch high. 
 
 Maneuvering clearances for sliding/folding doors: 
 • Approach from front: Minimum 48 inches perpendicular to doorway and 0 inches parallel to doorway 
 
 • Approach from side: Minimum 42 inches perpendicular to doorway and 0 inches parallel to doorway 
 
 • Approach from hinge side: Minimum 42 inches perpendicular to doorway and 22 inches parallel to doorway 
 
 • Approach from latch/knob side: Minimum 42 inches perpendicular to doorway and 24 inches parallel doorway 
 
 • See Section 404 for more detail and graphics.

• Toilets must be positioned with a wall to the rear and to one side. 
 
 • The center of the toilet must be 16 to 18 inches from the side wall or partition. 
 
 • Clearance must be 60 inches minimum perpendicular from the side wall and 56 inches minimum perpendicular from the rear wall for wall hung toilets or 59 inches minimum for floor mounted toilets. For children, the stall should be 60 inches wide and 59 inches deep minimum. 
 
 • Seat height must be 17 inches minimum and 19 inches maximum from the floor for adults. 
 
 • The side wall grab bar must be 42 inches long minimum and be placed a maximum of 12 inches from the rear wall. 
 
 • The rear wall grab bar must be 36 inches long minimum and extend from the center of the toilet 12 inches minimum on one side and 24 inches on the other. 
 
 • Doors can only be in the front or side partition of the stall. They must open outward, be 32 or 36 inches wide, be self-closing and a maximum of 4 inches from the side wall or partition farthest from the toilet.

• Ambulatory stalls are for people who walk with the assistance of canes or crutches. 
 
 • Center of the toilet must be 17 to 19 inches from the side wall or partition. 
 
 • Seat height must be 11 inches minimum and 17 inches maximum from the floor. 
 
 • Toilets must be positioned with a wall to the rear and on each side. 
 
 • Stall must have a depth of 60 inches minimum (from the back wall to the partition/door) and width of 35 inches minimum and 37 inches maximum. 
 
 • Grab bars on each side of the stall. Each bar should measure 42 inches long minimum and be located a maximum of 12 inches from the rear wall. 
 
 • Doors must swing outward, be self-closing, and have a 32 inch door.

• The width of walking surfaces must be 36 inches wide, minimum, and clear of obstructions. 
 
 • At turns of 180 degrees around an element that is less than 48 inches wide, the clear width must be 42 inches minimum approaching the turn, 48 inches minimum at the turn and 42 inches minimum leaving the turn. 
 
 • Accessible routes with clear width of less than 60 inches, passing spaces must be provided at intervals of 200 feet maximum. Passing spaces must either be a space 60 inches minimum by 60 inches minimum, or an intersection of two walking surfaces providing a T-shaped space where the arms extend 48 inches minimum beyond the intersection.

• The maximum steepness of a slope is 1:12. 
 
 • Ramps should have the least possible running slope and, when possible, accompany them with stairs. 
 
 • Cross slope of ramp runs shall not be steeper than 1:48. 
 
 • Clear width of a ramp run and, where handrails are provided, the clear width between handrails must be 36 inches minimum. 
 
 • The rise for any ramp run shall only be 30 inches maximum.

• Ramps must have landings at the top and bottom of each ramp run. 
 
 • Circular landing spaces must have a minimum turning space of 60 inches in diameter. 
 
 • T-shaped turning spaces must exist within square of 60 inches by 60 inches minimum size. The arms and base of the T must be a minimum of 36 inches wide. Each arm must be clear of obstructions for a minimum distance of 12 inches in each direction and the base should be clear of obstructions for a minimum distance of 24 inches.

Enter the total number of parking spots in the text box. Then, click calculate. The calculator computes the minimum number of accessible parking spaces needed based on the total number of parking spaces provided in the parking lot or parking structure.

• Car parking spaces must be at least 96 inches wide and van parking spaces must be at least 132 inches wide, each must be marked to define the width, and each must have an adjacent access aisle. 
 
 • The length of accessible parking spaces is the same as standard parking spaces, which the standard DOT recommendation is 228 inches. 
 
 • Access aisles must be at least 60 inches wide, the same length as the parking space, and marked to discourage parking in them. 
 
 • For hospital outpatient facilities, ten percent of patient and visitor parking spaces provided must be accessible parking spaces. 
 
 • For rehabilitation facilities and outpatient physical therapy facilities, twenty percent of patient and visitor parking spaces must be accessible parking spaces. 
 
 • In general, accessible parking spaces must be located on the shortest accessible route from parking to the entrance of the particular building or facility they serve. 
 
 • For residential facilities, accessible parking spaces must be located on the shortest accessible route to the dwelling unit entrance they serve and should be dispersed throughout all types of parking provided for the residential dwelling units.
